Award.AwardTitle: Computational Modeling of Interiors of Sub-Neptunes and Gas Giant Planets
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI and his team will carry out a theoretical effort to improve understanding of the interior, formation and evolution of ice- and gas-giant planets in our solar system and other extrasolar planetary systems. They will apply computer simulations techniques to study planetary interior materials exposed to extreme temperatures and pressures that cannot be reproduced in the laboratory. They will do this by simulating thermodynamic properties of the gases, such as the equation of state (EOS), which gives the mathematical relationship between temperature, pressure and density of a material. The investigators will apply their models to a collection of ice giant planets with masses less than that of Neptune. They also plan to develop a new model for Uranus' and Neptune's interior that includes a diamond layer, in order to explain these planets' peculiar magnetic fields. They will work with collaborators to prepare complementary high-pressure experiments, and to update models of Jupiter and Saturn. Computational results will be provided to the astronomical community for use in planetary and stellar interior models. They will also train graduate and undergraduate students in computational research techniques.

The investigators will accomplish this by incorporating the group's new ab initio Hydrogen-Helium EOS into existing code in order to model rotating giant planets. They will also update phase diagrams for liquid and superionic water and simulate the mixtures of water, methane and ammonia in these planets. They will use these results to improve evolutionary models of Jupiter and Saturn, and magnetic field models of Uranus and Neptune. They will also incorporate the EOS tables into the stellar evolution code MESA, and provide results to the community about ab initio Gibbs free energy calculations in solid, liquid, superionic and lower-density molecular systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the deep interiors of planets, materials exist under high pressures and temperatures that approach or exceed the capabilities of state of the art experimental techniques. For this reason, numerical simulations of materials are essential for understanding the structure and evolution of both the planets in our solar system and the growing catalogue of exoplanets. A key advance was the refinement of the thermodynamic integration method for calculating the entropy of Density Functional Theory Molecular Dynamics simulations. This enabled the team to study the energetics of mixing between materials under planetary conditions. This included determining the solubility of water, silica and iron in the metallic hydrogen envelopes of giant planets, as well as the miscibility of terrestrial mantle and core materials during an energetic giant impact event. The team also made advances in the calculation of equations of state for materials under planetary conditions, including ternary mixtures of hydrogen and helium with various heavy elements in the envelopes of giant plants.  With computer simulations, the team also predicted a series of novel materials to form high pressure including superionic H2O, H2O2, and H9O4 as well as new H2O-NaCl and carbon-oxygen and silicon-carbon compounds.

In addition to materials simulations, the group also made advances in techniques for modelling planets on a global scale, which provides an important link between the material properties found in simulations and the observable features of planets. This work focused on the development of the Concentric Maclaurin Spheroid method for efficient, precise calculations of the shape and gravitational field of fluid planets. A part of this project was dedicated to extending the theory to three dimensions to include the tidal response to a satellite and integrating it with a Monte Carlo approach for exploring parameters of interior models based on first-principles equations of state. These developments were used to make improved predictions for the tidal love numbers of Jupiter and Saturn. It was also integral to a collaborative effort in providing the initial models to explain the recent measurements of Jupiter by the Juno spacecraft, and Saturn during the Cassini spacecraft's grand finale. These results suggest a dilute core to exist in the interior of Jupiter.

Results from this project were reported at scientific conferences and in over 22 peer reviewed publications including, “F. Soubiran, B. Militzer, Electronic conductivity and magnetic dynamos in magma oceans of Super-Earths, Nature Communications 9 (2018) 3883.” The results have been shared with collaborators from a variety of institutions as part of the interiors working group of the Juno Science Team.Four postdoctoral researchers, three PhD students, and three undergraduate students were trained in computer simulation of matter at extreme conditions. Two of them now pursue a career in this field at LLNL.
